titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the General John Sedgwick Papers 1776-1994 (Bulk 1776-1950) MS 034 MS 034 MS 034
titlestmt.author: Processed by Ryan Bachman

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2017-02-02 07:42:08 -0800.

did.abstract: This collection contains items related to Union Army general and Cornwall native, John Sedgwick (1813-1864).

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The collection was begun through the collections of town historian E.C. Starr, but was expanded and organized by subsequent historians and presidents of the Cornwall Historical Society, such as Emily E. Marsh and Michael Gannett.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); The General John Sedgwick Papers; MS 034; box number; folder number; Cornwall Historical Society

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: John Sedgwick (1813-1864) was born in Cornwall Hollow on September 13, 1813 to one of the community’s most prominent families. He taught school in his hometown for two winters before entering the United States Military Academy at West Point, where he graduated in 1837. Prior to the Civil War, Sedgwick fought as an artillery officer in the Seminole War, took part in the removal of the Cherokee from Georgia, and served first as a captain, and later as a major, in the Mexican-American War. Following the Mexican-American War, Sedgwick served for several years in Western United States, first in Utah and later in Kansas. By 1860, his personal correspondence reveals that Sedgwick was ready to retire from military life and return to Cornwall; the start of the Civil War put a stop to those plans.

At the beginning of the war, Sedgwick held the rank of colonel, and served with distinction in the Eastern Theater, resulting in a promotion to the rank of general. In 1862 at the Battle of Antietam, Sedgwick had two horses shot from under him, and received three wounds. After being carried off of the battlefield, Sedgwick returned to Cornwall to convalesce in his recently-completed new home. After a brief recovery period, Sedgwick returned to the Eastern Theater, and fought at the battles of Chancellorsville and Gettysburg. On May 9, 1864, at Spotsylvania, Virginia, after his troops came under fire from a sharpshooter, Sedgwick refused to take cover and chided his men for their fear of marksmen so far away; Sedgwick was then shot under the left eye and killed instantly. His body was transported home and laid to rest in the Cornwall Hollow Cemetery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains six archival boxes of material. The first three boxes contain the personal papers of General John Sedgwick and are organized into categories devoted to his military service and correspondence. The fourth box contains items related to Sedgwick’s family, while the final two containers hold information concerning memorials to General Sedgwick.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged chronologically by subject then chronologically within each subject.
The files are grouped into 5 series:
